Key Arguments: The bill poses a danger to freedom of speech in Australia.
There are no legal protections against subjective judgments by unelected public servants.
The definition of harm is too broad and open to interpretation, leading to potential injustices.
The bill creates an environment of fear, discouraging citizens from speaking out on social or conscience issues.
Free speech is a non-negotiable human right that must be safeguarded.
The bill could lead to unjust criminal convictions based on subjective interpretations.
Australians have experienced restrictions on their speech in recent years, and this bill exacerbates the issue.
Notable Quotes: Freedom of speech is our most valued intangible asset.
An unnatural hothouse environment of fear would prevail, in which citizens will not feel they are able to speak out in matters of conscience or even social issues for fear of being victimized.
Free speech is a non-negotiable human right and must be safeguarded.
